The British weren‚Äôt far behind and they made far better use of their technology. It turns out technology is a tool and a good tool used well is superior to an excellent tool used poorly.

Answer: The Chinese had many great inventions. Just mentioning one will not be enough, so I will mention all the inventions in which without it we will not live in the world we know of today. In this answer, I will mention the most important Chinese inventions that most people do not know we invented.Though guns are frequently regarded to be a western invention, they actually originated from the eastern civilization of China. During the Song Dynasty an unknown man managed to make a smaller version of the cannon and create the first firearm. Today, in every war, you will find the gun.2. PorcelainPoThe Chinese had many great inventions. Just mentioning one will not be enough, so I will mention all the inventions in which without it we will not live in the world we know of today. In this answer, I will mention the most important Chinese inventions that most people do not know we invented.Though guns are frequently regarded to be a western invention, they actually originated from the eastern civilization of China. During the Song Dynasty an unknown man managed to make a smaller version of the cannon and create the first firearm. Today, in every war, you will find the gun.2. PorcelainPorcelain. A glass-like material used to make dishes, vases, cups etc in China. During the Han dynasty, the first porcelain grew to become the materials for great works of art and also for cups, teapots, plates, vases, and more. In most of history, demand for Chinese porcelain had always being high. It was, and still is, one of the most profitable things the Chinese empire has every created, with thousands of wealth entering China from the ancient days for the humble porcelain. China was so famous for it‚Äôs porcelain that porcelain had a nickname called China.3. Mechanical ClockDuring Tang Dynasty, the first mechanical clock was created, which is the ancestor of the digital clock that wakes you up every morning. The first mechanical clock was operated by water in the warmer months, and liquid mercury in winter. The water turns a series of cogs and mechanisms which operates the clock, though it doesn't count as a water clock as the water does not tell the time.4. AlcoholThough the invention of alcohol is frequently attributed to Arabs, a discovery in 2013 of pottery containing traces of alcohol from 9000 years ago passed the title of the first alcohol brewers from the Arabs, to the Chinese, who discovered this 1000 years earlier than them. Today, this drink is extremely popular in the modern society, perhaps too popular.5. RocketsMany people, especially westerners, do not know that the rockets, the invention that took us to the moon and beyond, came from Song Dynasty China, one thousand years ago. Though it was used as a weapon, this invention became one of the things that the west used to assert it‚Äôs dominance over science and technology in modern times. But this invention was not western at all, it came one thousand years ago from far off China.6. ToothbrushThe toothbrush. The object that helps keep our teeth shining white and stop them from falling out. This invention originated in Ming Dynasty, it was bought to the west via the silk road and form then on has been keeping the world with shining white teeth.7. BanknoteThe banknote, the thing we use to pay for our items we buy. This originated from Tang Dynasty China, from then on, the whole world has been printing them over the centuries.There are countless inventions the Chinese made, and they all helped shape the world.

Answer: For me, I think far more attention should be paid to the Chinese invention of artemisinin.It is often said that if you want to do the most good for the world, the two things you should focus on are public health policy and malaria.Well, China invented the current treatment for malaria:It is a compound originally extracted from sweet wormwood (scientific nomenclature:Artemisinin‚Äôs history comes from the Chinese military‚Äôs secret project, codenamed 523, whose purpoFor me, I think far more attention should be paid to the Chinese invention of artemisinin.It is often said that if you want to do the most good for the world, the two things you should focus on are public health policy and malaria.Well, China invented the current treatment for malaria:It is a compound originally extracted from sweet wormwood (scientific nomenclature:Artemisinin‚Äôs history comes from the Chinese military‚Äôs secret project, codenamed 523, whose purpose was to find a way to combat malaria affecting the Vietnamese soldiers during the US-Vietnam war. Upon the unification of Vietnam, the project no longer had military implications, but the research wasn‚Äôt open to the public until 1981.Most importantly, artemisinin from sweet wormwood could be produced extremely easily and‚ÄîToday, artemisinin-based medicine is the go-to treatment for malaria patients. Although not recommended as a monotherapy (i.e. as the only drug therapy) it still serves as the principle means of killing malaria microorganisms, which it can do at all stages of the organism‚Äôs life cycle.While the drug used to be distributed largely free of charge during the military project days, it has now been commercialized most notably by Novartis (Coartem). It is priced at $1200 US per kilogram - the above box would cost $6.944 each.

Answer: We aren‚Äôt really sure.The last major battle between the Communist and Nationalist forces on the mainland took place between March and April of 1950 as the Xichang Campaign.The campaign is widely recognized as the last major land battle of the Second Civil War, after that, there was basically no organized Nationalist resistance to speak of on the mainland.ÔºàThe Battle of Hainan Island in April of 1950 could also be the last land battle, but it took place on an island that is technically not ‚Äúmainland‚Äù.)However, Nationalist remnants scattered throughout China continued their fight, and it was quiWe aren‚Äôt really sure.The last major battle between the Communist and Nationalist forces on the mainland took place between March and April of 1950 as the Xichang Campaign.The campaign is widely recognized as the last major land battle of the Second Civil War, after that, there was basically no organized Nationalist resistance to speak of on the mainland.ÔºàThe Battle of Hainan Island in April of 1950 could also be the last land battle, but it took place on an island that is technically not ‚Äúmainland‚Äù.)However, Nationalist remnants scattered throughout China continued their fight, and it was quite a headache for the PRC leadership at the time because these scattered forces lacked a central leadership and were basically employing guerilla tactics.Many of the Nationalist forces were recruited or co-opted from criminals and bandits; after the Nationalist command system fell apart, they just simply took up their old trades as mountain bandits and highwaymen, using their Nationalist arms and supplies.So, from 1950 to 1953, the PRC fought with these rogue forces across mainland China. Although these battles are usually viewed separately from the Civil War, and are instead collectively known as the ‚ÄùBandit Extermination Battles‚Äù.The poster says ‚ÄúSo long as the bandits remain, the army will not retreat.‚ÄùCaptured bandit forces with army-supplied heavy machine guns and mortarsBy the conclusion of the campaign in 1953, approximately 2.4 million bandits were killed, captured, or have surrendered.So you could say that the last ROC resistance in Mainland China fell in 1953; although whether they are really ‚ÄúROC‚Äù is up for debate.And there are accounts about the last of these bandits surviving into the 1960s and even 70s, although I tend to view them more as fanciful stories than anything actually reliable.

And find a way to satisfy their needs.There‚Äôs a small fruit and vegetable store that opened recently, a few blocks from my home. They sell fresh fruits, vegetables, dairy products and some meat products too. They are always busy, year round. They do very well. As they recently expanded and opened another store.They sell basic products. Similar products you can get from any grocer near you. No grand new invention or a revolutionary business idea. But why do they do so well?The owner simply identified a gap in the markSo many startups do well, because they understand the needs of the consumers. And find a way to satisfy their needs.There‚Äôs a small fruit and vegetable store that opened recently, a few blocks from my home. They sell fresh fruits, vegetables, dairy products and some meat products too. They are always busy, year round. They do very well. As they recently expanded and opened another store.They sell basic products. Similar products you can get from any grocer near you. No grand new invention or a revolutionary business idea. But why do they do so well?The owner simply identified a gap in the market. There weren‚Äôt a lot of stores that sold fresh, organic products in the area.And all he does differently is, he consistently provides his customers with fresh, quality products. And focuses on managing the relationships with his customers well.You will always see the owner stroll through his store. Communicating with his customers, asking questions. Always with a smile. Such as: ‚Äúdo you need any help?‚Äù ; ‚ÄúIs there anything else you need?‚Äù; ‚ÄúDid you notice, our fresh blueberries arrived yesterday!‚ÄùCustomers appreciate this. And thus became loyal to his business. But it‚Äôs not just the owner that contributes to the overall success. It‚Äôs the employees too. They treat you with the same manner of respect and decency as how the owner does.Let‚Äôs summarize it. ‚ÄúWhy do some startups do well?‚Äù1.) They simply satisfy a need by filling a gap in the market2.) Consistently provide quality products3.) They understand their customers, by continuously communicating with them, in a way they appreciate and understand4.) They work hard, and are always on the floor ensuring their customers are satisfied5.) They Implement their business model well!
